newsitem.title: USA: Martha Stewart may spin off retail stores.
newsitem.headline: Martha Stewart may spin off retail stores.

text.p: Martha Stewart, the stockbroker turned empress of entertaining, said Tuesday her $200 million gardening, food and decorating empire may start a chain of retail stores and hinted a stock offering may be coming.
With public appetite for her lifestyle of studied elegance growing, her company is developing a long-term strategy to meet the demand, she told the National Press Club.

A line of paints based on the colors of eggs produced by her chickens is now available. Articles on how to make wreaths of freeze-dried Black-Eyed Susans and hand-paint gift wrap have led to soaring sales for her Martha Stewart Living magazine. "Martha By Mail" sells her project kits.

Stewart, the woman other women either admire or disdain, told the audience she vacuums to relax and finds her career, being Martha Stewart, is her life. Fulfilling public desire for the "Martha Stewart" product now requires a staff of 140 in her New York offices and on her Westport, Conn. mini-farm.

While she approves projects, the staff started work on ideas for this year's Christmas photo settings and projects five days after last Christmas. She will have "celebrated" Christmas six times before she gets to the real one with her family in December.
Retail stores are one of the options being considered as the company maps its future, she said. "Those kinds of things will be forthcoming," she said.
Asked whether her entertaining, cooking and decorating enterprise would issue stock, the former stockbroker replied with a smile, "We love the stock market."

Stewart's long-term goal is to turn her company, which started with one book on entertaining in 1982, into a full-fledged information company with an interactive site on the Internet and expanded versions of her television series produced by Martha Stewart Living Television.
But ideas, not product evaluation, will be the focus. "I am not so much interested in telling people what to buy, as how to live," Stewart said.
She acknowledged that the projects she suggests require more time than most people have, but whether or not people actually make her cranberry wreaths, it is the idea that sells.
"Many of us are dreamers and not doers. If you can find time to do both, it is nice," she said.
